results.name: Triangle of coefficients for expressing x^n in terms of Hermite polynomials.
comment: These polynomials, H_n(x), are an Appell sequence, whose umbral compositional inverse sequence HI_n(x) consists of the same polynomials signed with the e.g.f. e^{-t^2} e^{xt}. Consequently, under umbral composition H_n(HI.(x)) = x^n = HI_n(H.(x)). Other differently scaled families of Hermite polynomials are A066325, A099174, and A060821. See Griffin et al. for a relation to the Catalan numbers and matrix integration. - _Tom Copeland_, Dec 27 2020
reference: M. Abramowitz and I. A. Stegun, eds., Handbook of Mathematical Functions, National Bureau of Standards Applied Math. Series 55, 1964 (and various reprintings), p. 801. (Table 22.12)

Index entries for sequences related to Hermite polynomials
formula: E.g.f. (rel to x): A(x, y) = exp(x*y + x^2).
Sum_{ k>=0 } 2^k*k!*T(m, k)*T(n, k) = T(m+n, 0) = |A067994(m+n)|. - _Philippe Deléham_, Jul 02 2005
T(n, k) = 0 if n-k is odd; T(n, k) = n!/(k!*((n-k)/2)!) if n-k is even. - _Philippe Deléham_, Jul 02 2005
The n-th row entries may be obtained from D^n(exp(x*t)) evaluated at x = 0, where D is the operator sqrt(1+4*x)*d/dx. - _Peter Bala_, Dec 07 2011

As noted in the comments this is an Appell sequence of polynomials, so the lowering and raising operators defined by L H_n(x) = n H_{n-1}(x) and R H_{n}(x) = H_{n+1}(x) are L = D_x, the derivative, and R = D_t log[e^{t^2} e^{xt}] |_{t = D_x} = x + 2 D_x, and the polynomials may also be generated by e^{-D^2} x^n = H_n(x). - _Tom Copeland_, Dec 27 2020
maple: for n from 0 to 11 do seq(T(n, k), k=0..n) od; # _Peter Luschny_, Jan 05 2021
program: (PARI) for(n=0,20, for(k=0,n, print1(round(n!*(1+(-1)^(n+k))/(2*k! *gamma((n-k+2)/2)), ", "))) \\ _G. C. Greubel_, Jun 09 2018
